texts.shortText:
Familiar blue colonian hydrozoan that floats on the water surface and is frequently cast ashore following onshore winds. The colony is supported by a large inflated float with a crimped upper margin. Hanging beneath this are other zooids specialized for prey capture, feeding or reproduction. Most conspicuous are the long trailing tentacles used for prey capture and which can be extended many meters below the float, or contracted into a tight spiral. These are armed with conspicuous nematocysts which can inflict a painful sting.

Until recently all bluebottles were grouped under the one name Physalia physalis, but recent research has shown that there are in fact 4 species and some earlier names, including this one, have now been re-established. This species can be recognised by the medium-sized, elevated and strongly crimped crest to the float, which has a purple to pink upper margin and a fairly long often upturned ‘float-tail’; by the gap between two group of hanging zooids and by usually one very long major feeding tentacle (and second but shorter main one). Colour also appears to be distinctive with this species having a combination of a purple crest margin and mostly evenly blue-whitish (no red) tentacles and zooids.
Floats typically 50 mm long, but stinging tentacles can be over 10 m when extended, typically 300 mm when contracted.

Global:  Widespread in tropical Indo-Pacific

Local/Regional: Whole region but un-common on west coast.

Floats on the ocean surface, where driven along at the mercy of prevailing winds blowing on the sail. There are both left and right-handed individuals, so these will be driven in different directions by the wind. The extremely long feeding tentacles extend far below the float and are used to capture prey swimming in the water column. The stinging cells are very venomous and can paralyse even quite large fish, which are then ‘reeled in’ by contraction of the tentacle and engulfed by feeding ‘gastrozooids’ for digestion and distribution of the nutrients among colony members.

Bluebottles can inflict painful and even dangerous stings, so should not be handled, even after they have been washed up on beaches, as the nematocysts remain potent for many hours after death. Swimming in the presence of bluebottles is also dangerous, as the extended tentacles can wrap around the body and inflict long, painful welts of stings. Despite their strong venom they are fed upon by several predators, including Sea swallow nudibranchs, plough shells and loggerhead turtles.
Feed on small fish, as well as on planktonic crustaceans.

Each colony is either male or female and eggs and sperm are shed into the water, where they merge to form larvae that drift in the water column and bud off new zooids as they develop. Once a pneumatophore or float-forming zooid is formed, the developing colony rises to the surface and begin its adult life.

Genus unmistakable and perhaps the best known of all hydrozoans. Two species are currently reported from South Africa, the other being P. utriculus which has a lower, more even sail (almost no ‘crimp’) without a pink margin, a short ‘float-tail’, only one major feeding tentacle that is comparatively shorter, deep blue tentacles and feeding zooids, the latter having bright yellow mouth openings. Being an Atlantic species the true Physalia physalis may also well extend down into South African waters. Of all species it has the largest crest with a bright pink margin, no gap between two group of hanging zooids, four or many major feeding tentacles, and red-purple tentacles and feeding zooids.
